thread.title: Four-month-old baby suffers serious head injuries after pram was hit by car
thread.title_full: Four-month-old baby suffers serious head injuries after pram was hit by car

author: Annette Belcher
title: Four-month-old baby suffers serious head injuries after pram was hit by car
text:
Get daily     
A four-month-old baby suffered head injuries after her pram was hit by a car . 
The infant girl was rushed to hospital after being thrown from her stroller in the horror accident in Pinfold Street, Darlaston, Walsall. 
The car hit the pram outside Darlaston Medical Centre at 10.15am, the Birmingham Mail reported . 
A West Midlands Ambulance Service spokesman said: " The four-month-old girl came out of the pushchair as a result of the collision. 
“She had suffered injuries to both arms and her head. 
"After treatment at the scene, she was taken to Walsall Manor Hospital for further assessment with her mother travelling with her. 
“There were no other patients.” Read More Tributes paid to "perfect princess" student killed after car went into ditch and hit tree as inquest opened The baby's pram was hit by a car on Pinfold Street in Darlaston (Photo: Twitter/Doug James) 
John Cownley, owner of Cownley barbers on Pinfold Street, said: “I saw the ambulance turn up and I heard that the buggy was thrown into the air. 
“I believe the child is very young, possibly only a few months old. 
‘The road is very busy and drivers do speed along here. An elderly woman, one of my customers, was hit by a taxi on the zebra crossing just 12 months ago. 
‘She was very badly injured.” The four-month-old tot suffered head and arm injuries (Photo: Twitter/Doug James) 
Local shopkeepers agreed that the stretch of road had already been the scene of several accidents. 
“This is a very busy road and there have been several accidents along here in the past year alone,” said one. 
“It is particularly dangerous at that junction because you have the traffic joining Pinfold Street from the dual carriageway. 
“And drivers can put their foot down there, at times.” Read More Driver SCREAMS in horror as he collides with 'drunk' man standing in middle of unlit country road Witnesses said the infant was 'very badly injured' (Photo: Twitter/Doug James) 
Jagdeep Gill, manager of Jhoots Pharmacy, added: “I saw the emergency services arrive and the road was closed off for a while. 
“We do often witness pedestrians walking out into the road without even looking. 
“But equally, cars will speed along and not slow down – so there are problems on both sides.” 
The road was closed between Wolverhampton Street and King Edward Street while investigations took place. 
A West Midlands Police spokeswoman said: “There was a collision between a car and a pushchair. A baby has been taken to the hospital.” Like us on Facebook
